So many games about introspection, from shenmue to Indigo Prophecy or life is strange and heavy rain, giving the player the ability to control and live someone else's life, to tell a compelling story and yet reflexive.

some games indeed strive for choice and interactivity, real choice, introspection, and yet, there is no introspection in these games, we don't realize what we do, there is no meaning in the action, only in the outcome. there is no motivation, we objectify the world and the characters, we 'choose' for them, they have a life and personality, at least perceived life. we give them advice, like we do with people in real life and we usually expect an outcome.

we could say "games as just made for profit", but the people who do it, do it for more than that.

They really invest resources into realizing their ideas, no matter how many compromises are made along the way, they do have a 'heart'.

the end of art, at least the end of a concept, do we do things to get to the end? as Allan Watts said "life is not a journey" "[...]  When dancing you don't aim at a particular spot in the room to arrive to it, the purpose of dancing is to dance".

and yet we do arrive to an end, eventually, eventually some perfectly conceive our ideas. its interesting how devastatingly simple they can look. 

the end of art as [Arthur Danto saw in Warhol's brillo box](https://www.warhol.org/arthur-danto-on-andy-warhols-brillo-box/).

...introspection, how the hell do we do that, well, it can take from 5 minutes to many hours:

`Internal error: IOError: [Errno 2] No such file or directory: u'../Local/ZeroNet-win-dist/data/13CgSQeywg2ius5pjXVCk7dKUCRkz5xvW3/filters/sites.json'
UiWebsocket.py line 81 > UiWebsocket.py line 265 > ContentFilterPlugin.py line 146 > SiteStorage.py line 303 > SiteStorage.py line 197`

idk if its a good thing to just mirror content (mostly videos that haven't or won't go down anyway) on zeronet... people will eventually start uploading their ~~more~~ own content on [kxovid](http://127.0.0.1:43110/14c5LUN73J7KKMznp9LvZWkxpZFWgE1sDz/?/) or [kopykate](http://127.0.0.1:43110/big.kopykate.bit/?Home), etc. maybe it makes sense to upload (mirrors) them on peertube.

but maybe some things make sense to mirror. like cppcon or jsconf videos...

if we can make an argument that some content would make sense to mirror and make a habit of uploading them here, people may gradually start using more platforms like kopykate and kxovid and eventually adopt it.

i think we can extend this way of thinking about uploading content that people actually want to see it here.

another thing that comes to mind is that content creation is usually done by one or more people planning a subject of interest.

we all have ideas that we would like to hear or talk about.
it can be cumbersome to just start making a video or any kind of content alone. editing, research, mixing, revision, etc.

what i'm getting at is, there could be a platform for content creation with collaboration in mind, you pitch an idea, leave there, people may join in. we could 'like' the ideas so these ideas gain more visibility.

and it could be very interactive i would argue. we could criticize ideas (which is the basis for improvement), improve it in many ways, etc. kinda like a github.

much like any other platform, it may be used or not, but it could not only facilitate content creation but actually make it possible.

there are many implications with it of course, if anyone is interested i could go through step by step on how this platform could work theoretically.

[Britannica](https://www.britannica.com/science/conflict-psychology)

>Conflicts are often unconscious, in the sense that the person cannot clearly identify the source of his distress. Many strong impulses—such as fear and hostility—are so much disapproved by the culture that a child soon learns not to acknowledge them, even to himself. >Permissions and Restrictions
>You may access and use the Service as made available to you, as long as you comply with this Agreement and applicable law. You may view or listen to Content for your personal, non-commercial use. You may also show YouTube videos through the embeddable YouTube player.

>The following restrictions apply to your use of the Service. You are not allowed to:

>access, reproduce, download, distribute, transmit, broadcast, display, sell, license, alter, modify or otherwise use any part of the Service or any Content except: (a) as expressly authorized by the Service; or (b) with prior written permission from YouTube and, if applicable, the respective rights holders;

i'm nowhere near of being an expert but that last *and* is very problematic, is youtube ToS implying that youtube has lawful precedence in choosing whether someone is able to reproduce content hosted on its website?

i mean, that sounds like it contradicts any sort of copyright law but if the uploader agrees with youtube ToS by default then it gives youtube power to harass anyone it doesn't like for instance backups like archive.org and it can always say that its doing that to "protect" content creators in the same fashion that publishers and producers do to artists. this is truly evil if i'm getting this right.

Everyone knows about the "Carrot and stick" principle which is used to influence recompense and punishment in a system.

By taking China's "Social Credit System" as purported by the western media, where is the carrot? i mean, if the carrot is as easy as being complacent then we have an inefficient system as most people can participate, benefit and of course manipulate it, rendering it meaningless. (e.g: anyone could create posts on social media to how much the love the CPC or go further than that).

looking elsewhere the carrot then could be "lack of punishment" making the whole purpose of the "Social Credit System" to punish and not to reward which doesn't make sense since it is used for financial purposes, one must be able to reward success.

so, on purely epistemological grounds the "Social Credit System"  (as purported by the western media) doesn't make any sense whatsoever. feel free to correct me.

Surveillance will keep us safe from our enemies, we say, obediently accepting the pronouncements of our governments on the identities of our enemies and the proper sources of our terror.

Only by going back and understanding the roots of modern (perhaps apparent) structures can we properly criticize surveillance, governments and their various kinds.

after finally getting the effing valorant key and installing riot's vanguard anticheat with kernel mode driver (the only thing that makes me feel more vulnerable than actually running windows or having jre on the path variables) the game is kinda boring, especially compared to csgo.

neither are open-source but csgo is probably the best commercial kinda of game because you can modify everything on the go with a console, create your own stuff, download other user's creations and host private&custom servers.

**i also have something to add about the possibility of open-source competitive games.**

csgo has lots of cheaters, like every single match has one or more cheaters, valve's VAC anti-cheat is very mild and not very intrusive but also not very effective. in contrast valorant's vanguard anti-cheat is way more effective and intrusive. 

this may give the idea that freedom needs to be sacrificed if you want to play competitive games without cheaters but i think that this is only an issue with *closed-source software*.

why? because a company like valve, riot or blizzard can simply host servers for their clients, once that is done nothing else is needed, you are just hosting a big party to which anyone can join in, mostly without any restrictions and the anti-cheat in this analogy is like a imperfect ticket checker.

oth open-source software or at least customizable non-free software gives users the ability to customize the experience and have extra "managerial steps" on the process.
